questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a red, "slapped cheek" rash and a low-grade fever. The parent mentions that the rash started a few days after the child had a mild flu-like illness. On examination, the rash appears as a bright red erythema on the cheeks with a lacy, reticular pattern on the trunk and limbs. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Parvovirus B19 is a small, non-enveloped DNA virus, belonging to the Parvoviridae family.
  • It primarily infects human erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.
  • Transmission occurs through respiratory droplets, transplacentally from mother to fetus, or via blood transfusions.

2. Clinical Manifestations

  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease): Characterized by a "slapped cheek" rash on the face, followed by a lacy rash on the body. Most common in children.
  • Arthropathy: Common in adults, presenting with symmetric polyarthritis resembling rheumatoid arthritis, especially in women.
  • Aplastic Crisis: Seen in patients with chronic hemolytic anemias (e.g., sickle cell disease), where infection leads to a transient halt in red blood cell production.
  • Fetal Complications: Infection in pregnant women can cause nonimmune hydrops fetalis due to severe anemia in the fetus, leading to heart failure.

Fever with rash in children

  • Option A): Measles typically presents with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, followed by a characteristic maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward. It does not usually present with a "slapped cheek" appearance or the lacy, reticular pattern seen in parvovirus B19 infection.
  • Option B): Roseola, also known as sixth disease or exanthem subitum presents with a high fever followed by a rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the limbs. The rash in roseola is usually rose-pink and non-pruritic.
  • Option C) Fifth disease (Parvovirus B19): Fifth disease, also known as erythema infectiosum, is caused by Parvovirus B19. It characteristically presents with a "slapped cheek" rash and a lacy, reticular rash on the body. The initial presentation with a mild flu-like illness followed by these rash patterns aligns with Parvovirus B19 infection.
  • Option D) Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is caused by Group A Streptococcus and is characterized by sandpaper-like rash that often starts in the groin and armpits and spreads outward. The rash usually has a diffuse, rough texture and is accompanied by a strawberry tongue. It does not present with the "slapped cheek" appearance or the lacy pattern.

Key Takeaway - Fifth disease, caused by Parvovirus B19, is known for its characteristic "slapped cheek" rash and subsequent lacy reticular rash on the body. It often follows a mild prodromal illness and should be differentiated from other exanthematous diseases based on clinical presentation.

TAG LINE - MODERATE

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Fifth Disease (Parvovirus B19)." CDC, updated August 29, 2023. Available at: CDC Fifth Disease

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with a painful, unilateral rash on the right chest. The rash began as small red spots that have evolved into fluid-filled vesicles, some of which have crusted over. The patient also reports burning pain and sensitivity in the affected area. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Shingles is caused by the reactivation of the Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV), the same virus that causes chickenpox. After initial infection (chickenpox), the virus remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglia and can reactivate later in life.

Rash distribution:

Unilateral

Segmental due to dermatosomal distribution

Painful vesicular lesions

Doesn't cross midline

  • Option A) Herpes simplex virus typically causes oral or genital lesions, presenting as painful vesicles in clusters. Although it can cause similar vesicular lesions, these are usually bilateral or localized to the mucosal area
  • Option B) Shingles is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which causes chickenpox. It presents with a unilateral vesicular rash that follows a dermatomal distribution. The rash often starts with burning pain and sensitivity before the appearance of vesicles and can involve the chest or other body areas, making this the correct diagnosis for unilateral chest rashes.
  • Option C) Contact dermatitis typically results from exposure to an allergen or irritant and presents with erythema, swelling, and itching rather than a vesicular rash. It is usually bilateral and localized to the area of contact.
  • Option D) Erysipelas is a bacterial skin infection usually caused by Group A Streptococcus. It presents with a well-defined, red, swollen, and painful rash that often has a distinct edge. It is usually not vesicular and does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

Key Takeaway - Shingles (Herpes Zoster) is characterized by a unilateral vesicular rash that follows a dermatomal distribution and is associated with burning pain and sensitivity. It results from the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which initially causes chickenpox.

Tag Line - Moderate

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Shingles (Herpes Zoster)." CDC, updated August 22, 2023. Available at: CDC Shingles

questions.text: A 28-year-old immunocompromised patient undergoes a retinal biopsy due to suspected retinitis. The histological examination of the biopsy shows large cells with intranuclear inclusions, often surrounded by a clear halo. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these microscopic findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CMV chorioretinitis is the most common opportunistic infection virus in HIV and transplantation.

The histological examination of the biopsy shows large cells with intranuclear inclusions, often surrounded by a clear halo, known as OWL EYE appearance.

Transmission occurs by oral respiratory, and body secretions, less commonly by transplacental and sexual route.

  • Option A) Herpes simplex virus can cause retinal necrosis and other ocular conditions, but the microscopic appearance typically shows intranuclear inclusions with a different morphology, including eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions and ballooning degeneration.

Multinucleation, Moulding and Margination.

  • Option B) Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is characterized by large cells with intranuclear inclusions that have a distinct "owl-eye" appearance, often surrounded by a clear halo. These intranuclear inclusions are a hallmark of CMV infection
  • Option C) Toxoplasmosis lesions are characterized by a different histological appearance, often showing inflammatory cells and necrotizing retinitis. The diagnostic feature in toxoplasmosis is presence of granulomatous inflammation.
  • D) Chlamydia: Chlamydial infections can lead to conjunctivitis and other ocular conditions but do not typically produce intranuclear inclusions. Their microscopic findings are more related to inclusion bodies within cytoplasm rather than the "owl-eye" appearance seen with CMV.

Key Takeaway - The "owl-eye" intranuclear inclusions seen on microscopic examination are characteristic of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. This appearance is crucial for diagnosing CMV retinitis, especially in immunocompromised patients.

TAGLINE - MODERATE

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and Congenital CMV Infection." CDC, updated August 23, 2023. Available at: CDC CMV

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presents with a painful oral lesion on the tongue. On examination, the lesion appears as a white, creamy plaque with an underlying erythematous base. A biopsy of the lesion is performed, and the histological examination reveals an appearance consistent with the Reynold-Braude phenomenon. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
• REYNOLD BRAUDE phenomenon/Germ tube test is shown by candida albicans when candida is grown with growth factors
  • Forms chlamydospores in corn meal agar
  • Cells in a line - pseudohyphae
  • On SDA-Creamy/pasty/yeasty colonies.
  • CHROMAGAR - Used to differentiate different kinds of candida
  • Option A: Oral herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically presents with painful vesicles or ulcers, not white plaques. Histology often shows epithelial cell necrosis and viral inclusions
  • Option B) Candida Albicans Infection: Candida albicans causes oral thrush, which appears as white, creamy plaques on an erythematous base. The Reynold - Braude phenomenon refers to the histological feature of Candida infections where pseudohyphae and yeast forms are seen in the tissue. This is consistent with the diagnosis of Candida infection.
  • Option C) Oral Leukoplakia: Oral leukoplakia presents as white patches that cannot be scraped off, unlike Candida plaques which can be removed revealing an underlying red base. Leukoplakia is more associated with dysplastic changes
  • Option D) Lichen Planus: Oral lichen planus often presents with white, lacy striae or plaques, but these are typically more reticular and do not have the underlying erythematous base or the Reynold-Braude phenomenon associated with Candida.

Key Takeaway - The Reynold-Braude phenomenon, characterized by the presence of pseudohyphae and yeast forms in tissue samples, is indicative of a Candida albicans infection, commonly presenting as oral thrush with white plaques on an erythematous base.

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander. Section V- Opportunistic Mycoses 20. Candidiasis, page number: 401-433.

questions.text: A 45-year-old gardener presents with a chronic, non-healing ulcer on the right hand. The lesion began as a small nodule and has progressively developed into multiple, satellite nodules along the lymphatic drainage pathway. Histopathological examination of the biopsy reveals yeast cells with a characteristic cigar-shaped appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
• Sporothrix schenkii causes Rose Gardener's disease/sporotrichosis.
  • The lesion begins as a small nodule at the site of thorn prick and progressively develops into multiple, satellite nodules along the lymphatic drainage pathway.
  • Histopathological examination - in the centre there is a round-shaped cigar body-yeast and surrounding it there are projections - Splendor hoeppli (Ag-Ab reaction) and together it is called asteroid body.

Lymphocutaneous spread


Cigar shaped yeast and asteroid bodies


Rosettes of microconidia


  • Option A): Actinomycosis often presents with chronic, granulomatous infections that form sinuses or abscesses, sometimes with sulfur granules. The histopathology typically shows gram-positive, filamentous bacteria, not cigar-shaped yeast cells.
  • Option B) Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, is characterized by a primary cutaneous nodule that progresses along lymphatic pathways, forming multiple, satellite nodules. The microscopic examination reveals cigar-shaped yeast cells, which are typical of Sporotrichosis, making this the correct diagnosis.
  • Option C) Leishmaniasis: Leishmaniasis can present with cutaneous ulcers or nodules. The diagnosis is usually made by identifying amastigotes in tissue samples.
  • Option D) Blastomycosis: Blastomycosis presents with a broad-based budding yeast form and can cause skin lesions, but the yeast cells are typically larger and more spherical compared to the cigar-shaped appearance of Sporothrix schenckii.

Key Takeaway - Sporotrichosis is characterized by a chronic cutaneous lesion with satellite nodules following lymphatic pathways and is diagnosed by identifying cigar-shaped yeast cells in tissue samples.

TAGLINE - MODERATE

Reference:

  • Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Sporotrichosis." CDC, updated August 23, 2023. Available at: CDC Sporotrichosis
  • Kaufman, L. (2018). "Sporotrichosis: An Overview." Journal of Clinical Microbiology, 56(9), e00954-18.
  • Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander. Section III- Subcutaneous Mycoses-Sporotrichosis, page number: 229-251.

questions.text: A 52-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with a chronic, sinusoidal infection and is found to have an irregular, destructive mass in the maxillary sinus on imaging studies. A biopsy reveals septate hyphae with acute-angle branching. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A- acute angled branching less than 90°

SPE - septate-dichomatous branching

  • Option A) Cryptococcosis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, is characterized by yeast cells with thick capsules and is often identified using India ink preparation or mucicarmine stain
  • Option B) Aspergillosis: Aspergillosis, caused by Aspergillus species, is characterized by the presence of septate hyphae with acute-angle branching on histopathology. It often presents as a destructive sinus or pulmonary mass in immunocompromised patients, making it consistent with the findings described.
  • Option C) Histoplasmosis, caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, presents with small yeast cells within macrophages on histology, not septate hyphae and tuberculate macroconidia.
  • Option D) Candidiasis: caused by Candida species, usually presents with yeast forms or pseudohyphae rather than septate hyphae with acute-angle branching.

Key Takeaway - Aspergillosis is identified by the presence of septate hyphae with acute-angle branching. This is a key diagnostic feature for distinguishing it from other fungal infections.

TAGLINE - HARD

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander. Section V - Opportunistic Mycoses. Aspergillosis, page number: 524 - 554.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient with a history of HIV/AIDS presents with meningitis and neurological symptoms. On cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, the presence of yeast cells with a large, thick capsule is observed. A biopsy of a skin lesion shows yeast cells with a clear halo surrounding them. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B) Cryptococcus causes meningitis and neurological symptoms in immunocompromised individuals

  • CSF sample - stained with Indian ink or nigrosin
  • Brain biopsy - stained with mucicarmine stain.
  • Brownish appearance - bird seed/niger agar due to presence of Phenol oxidase or laccase enzyme.
  • Confirmatory test - LATEX AGGLUTINATION TEST
  • A) Aspergillosis: Aspergillosis is characterized by septate hyphae with acute-angle branching rather than yeast cells with a thick capsule. It is typically not associated with the large capsule or clear halo observed in Cryptococcosis.
  • B) Cryptococcosis: Cryptococcosis, caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, is identified by yeast cells with a large, thick capsule, often visualized with India ink preparation or mucicarmine staining. The clear halo surrounding the yeast cells is a hallmark feature, particularly noted in CSF and skin lesions.
  • C) Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum and is characterized by small yeast forms within macrophages. It does not exhibit the large capsule seen in Cryptococcosis.
  • D) Candidiasis: Candidiasis, caused by Candida species, presents with yeast cells or pseudohyphae but does not typically have the large, thick capsule seen in Cryptococcosis.

Key Takeaway - Cryptococcosis is distinguished by its large, thick capsule surrounding yeast cells, which can be identified using India ink preparation or mucicarmine stain. This is a key feature for diagnosing Cryptococcosis, especially in the context of meningitis and skin lesions in immunocompromised patients.

TAGLINE - MODERATE

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander. on V - Opportunistic Mycoses. Cryptococcosis, page number: 434-473.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a high fever, cough, and chest pain. A chest X-ray reveals a dense, lobar consolidation in the right lower lobe. Sputum Gram stain shows numerous Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci. What is the most likely causative agent of this infection based on the Gram stain findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B) Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci, that causes lobar pneumonia.

  • Optochin sensitive
  • Inulin fermentation
  • Bile soluble
  • Quellung reaction - has a capsule that swells when specific antibodies bind.

Primary diseases caused by S pneumoniae:

  • M: Meningitis
  • O: Otitis media (in children)
  • P: Pneumonia
  • S: Sinusitis
  • Option A) Staphylococcus aureus appears as Gram-positive cocci in clusters rather than diplococci. It can cause pneumonia but does not typically present with the lancet-shaped diplococci seen in pneumococcal infections.
  • Option B) Streptococcus pneumoniae is known for its characteristic lancet-shaped, Gram-positive diplococci. It is a common cause of lobar pneumonia and matches the description of the sputum Gram stain findings and clinical presentation.
  • Option C) Haemophilus influenzae appears as small Gram-negative rods or coccobacilli rather than Gram-positive diplococci.
  • Option D) Klebsiella pneumoniae is a Gram-negative rod and typically causes pneumonia with cavitary lesions rather than lobar consolidation. It does not present as Gram-positive diplococci.

Key Takeaway - Streptococcus pneumoniae is identified by its Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci and is a common cause of lobar pneumonia. This distinct appearance helps differentiate it from other bacterial pathogens.

TAGLINE - MODERATE

Reference: Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Pneumonia." CDC, updated August 22, 2023. Available at: CDC Pneumonia

questions.text:
The image below shows a typical bacterial growth curve with distinct phases labeled A, B, C, and D. Based on the image, identify the phase where the bacterial population is increasing at its maximum rate.

What is the correct label for the phase where the bacterial population is growing exponentially at its maximum rate?
questions.solution:
Log (Exponential) Phase is the phase where the bacterial population is growing exponentially at its maximum rate

  • A) Lag Phase: The Lag Phase is the initial phase of the bacterial growth curve where the bacteria are adapting to new conditions. During this phase, there is little to no cell division, and growth is not exponential.
  • B) Log (Exponential) Phase: The Log Phase, also known as the Exponential Phase, is where the bacterial population grows at its maximum rate. During this phase, the number of bacteria doubles at a constant rate, leading to rapid growth.
  • C) Stationary Phase: The Stationary Phase is where the growth rate slows down and stabilizes because the number of new cells created equals the number of cells dying. The overall population size remains constant.

S T A B:

S-Sporulation

T-Toxin production

A-Antibiotic production

B-Bacteriocin production

  • D) Death (Decline) Phase: The Death Phase is characterized by a decline in the bacterial population due to the accumulation of waste products and depletion of nutrients. The growth rate is negative, and the number of viable cells decreases.

Key Takeaway - The Log (Exponential) Phase of the bacterial growth curve is characterized by rapid, exponential growth of the bacterial population, where the number of cells increases at its maximum rate.

Reference:

  • Madigan, M. T., Martinko, J. M., Bender, K. S., Buckley, D. H., & Stahl, D. A. (2017). "Brock Biology of Microorganisms". Pearson Education.
  • Brock, T. D. (1970). "The Biology of Microorganisms." Prentice Hall.

questions.text: Which malaria parasite is represented by the ring form in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

  • A) Plasmodium vivax: The ring forms of P. vivax are typically more varied and may appear larger with more complex shapes compared to P. falciparum.
  • B) Plasmodium malariae: P. malariae ring forms are often more compact and can be seen in a more stacked or banded formation along with Band Shaped gametocytes
  • C) Plasmodium ovale: The ring forms of P. ovale are similar to those of P. vivax.
  • D) Plasmodium falciparum: The ring form of P. falciparum is characterized by its delicate, multiple ring and multiple dots (Stereo headphone appearance) along with banana-shaped gametocyte.

Key Takeaway

The ring form of Plasmodium falciparum is characterized by a delicate, single-ring shape with a central dot, which helps differentiate it from other Plasmodium species in blood smears.

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO). "Malaria Microscopy: Practical Manual." WHO, updated 2021. Available at: WHO Malaria Microscopy

questions.text: Which of the following images depicts the microscopic appearance of Candida albicans?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Image A depicts Candida albicans representing pseudohyphae.

  • REYNOLD BRAUDE phenomenon/Germ tube test is shown by candida albicans when candida is grown with growth factors
  • Forms chlamydospores in corn meal agar
  • Cells in a line -pseudohyphae
  • On SDA-Creamy/pasty/yeasty colonies.
  • CHROMAGAR-Used to differentiate different kinds of candida

Option A: Correct - Candida albicans often appears as yeast cells with pseudohyphae and is characterized by its budding yeast and hyphal forms.

Option B: Incorrect - Aspergillus fumigatus appears as a mold with conidial heads.

Option C: Incorrect - Histoplasma capsulatum appears as small yeast cells within macrophages.

Option D: Incorrect - Trichophyton rubrum appears as dermatophyte hyphae with branching.

Key Takeaway: The image shows the yeast and pseudohyphal forms of Candida albicans, commonly seen in infections like candidiasis.

TAG LINE: EASY

Reference: Shastri, A., & Bhatt, S. (2023). Essential Microbiology. Chapter 65, page number: 665-670

questions.text: The image below shows a blood smear with large, oval-shaped cells and a "maltese cross" appearance. Which parasite is this indicative of?
questions.solution:
B) Babesia spp - a blood smear with large, oval-shaped cells and a "maltese cross" appearance-Ring of terrad

  • Babesiosis is characterised by fever with chills and hemolytic anemia; asplenia increases the risk of severe disease due to inability to clear infected RBC's.
  • Definitive host - Hard tick
    Intermediate host - rodent/mammal
    Accidental dead-end host - humans
  • Treatment - Atovaquone and azithromycin

Explanation:

  • Option A: Incorrect - Plasmodium falciparum shows ring forms in red blood cells, not a maltese cross.
  • Option B: Correct - Babesia spp. is known for the "Maltese cross" appearance in blood smears.
  • Option C: Incorrect - Trypanosoma brucei shows trypomastigotes in blood smears, not a Maltese cross.
  • Option D: Incorrect - Leishmania donovani appears as amastigotes inside macrophages, not a Maltese cross.

Key Takeaway: The "Maltese cross" appearance in a blood smear is characteristic of Babesia spp., a protozoan parasite.

TAG LINE: HARD

Reference: Shastri, A., & Bhatt, S. (2023). Essential Microbiology. Chapter 55, page number: 555-560.

questions.text: The image below shows a chest X-ray with a "cavitary lesion" in the upper lobe. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with this type of lung lesion?
questions.solution:
• Cavitatory lesions in the lungs due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) occur as a result of the body's immune response to the infection. These lesions are often found in post-primary (reactivation) TB, which typically affects the upper lobes of the lungs. Here's an overview:

Pathophysiology of Cavitatory Lesions in TB

  • Inhalation and Initial Infection: tuberculosis reaches the alveoli and is engulfed by macrophages. The bacteria may survive within macrophages and initiate infection.
  • Granuloma Formation: The immune system forms granulomas to contain the infection. Granulomas consist of macrophages, T-cells, and other immune cells.
  • Caseation Necrosis: In post-primary TB (reactivation), the center of the granulomas undergoes caseation necrosis, forming a cheese-like material.
  • Cavity Formation: The necrotic material liquefies and drains via the bronchi, leaving behind air-filled cavities in the lung tissue. These are typically located in the upper lobes.
  • Progression: Cavities facilitate bacterial growth due to high oxygen tension, increasing bacterial load and transmission potential.

Explanation:

Option A: Correct - Mycobacterium tuberculosis is commonly associated with cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs.

Option B: Incorrect - Streptococcus pneumoniae typically causes lobar pneumonia, not cavitary lesions.

Option C: Incorrect - Legionella pneumophila causes pneumonia with a diffuse pattern rather than cavitary lesions.

Option D: Incorrect - Pseudomonas aeruginosa may cause lung infections but is less commonly associated with cavitary lesions.

Key Takeaway: Cavitary lung lesions are most commonly associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

The prognosis of cavitatory TB largely depends on early diagnosis and prompt initiation of treatment. Delayed or incomplete treatment can lead to complications like persistent cavities, chronic lung disease, or the spread of the infection to other areas.

TAG LINE: MODERATE

Reference: Shastri, A., & Bhatt, S. (2023). Essential Microbiology. Chapter 70, page number: 700-705.

questions.text: The image below shows a histological section of a lung biopsy with "cigar-shaped" yeast cells. Which fungal infection does this finding most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
• Sporothrix schenkii causes Rose Gardener's disease/sporotrichosis.
  • The lesion begins as a small nodule at the site of thorn prick and progressively develops into multiple, satellite nodules along the lymphatic drainage pathway.
  • Histopathological examination - in the centre there is a round-shaped cigar body-yeast and surrounding it there are projections - Splendor hoeppli (Ag-Ab reaction) and together it is called asteroid body.

Lymphocutaneous spread

Cigar shaped yeast and asteroid bodies

Explanation:

  • Option A: Incorrect - Blastomyces dermatitidis appears as broad-based budding yeast cells.
  • Option B: Incorrect - Coccidioides immitis appears as spherules containing endospores, not cigar-shaped yeast cells.
  • Option C: Correct - Sporothrix schenckii is characterized by "cigar-shaped" yeast cells and is associated with sporotrichosis.
  • Option D: Incorrect - Histoplasma capsulatum appears as small yeast cells within macrophages, not cigar-shaped.

Key Takeaway: "Cigar-shaped" yeast cells are indicative of Sporothrix schenckii, which causes sporotrichosis.

TAG LINE: MODERATE

Reference: Shastri, A., & Bhatt, S. (2023). Essential Microbiology. Chapter 64, page number: 645-650.

questions.text: The image below shows a Gram-stained smear from a wound infection. The bacteria appear as gram-negative rods with a characteristic "safety pin" appearance. Which bacterium is most likely identified in this smear?
questions.solution:
• Gram pleomorphic rod/coccobacillus with bipolar staining/Safety Pin appearance.
  • Usually transmitted from pet feces (eg, cats, dogs), contaminated milk, or pork.
  • Can cause acute bloody diarrhea, pseudoappendicitis (right lower abdominal pain due to mesenteric adenitis and/or terminal ileitis), reactive arthritis in adults.

Explanation:

Option A: Incorrect - Pseudomonas aeruginosa appears as gram-negative rods but does not have a safety pin appearance.

Option B: Correct - Yersinia pestis is known for its characteristic "safety pin" appearance in Gram-stained smears and is the causative agent of plague.

Option C: Incorrect - Escherichia coli appears as straight gram-negative rods, not with a safety pin appearance.

Option D: Incorrect - Klebsiella pneumoniae appears as gram-negative rods but does not have a safety pin appearance.

Key Takeaway: The "safety pin" appearance in Gram-stained smears is characteristic of Yersinia pestis, which causes plague.

TAG LINE: HARD

Reference: Shastri, A., & Bhatt, S. (2023). Essential Microbiology. Chapter 57, page number. 575-580.
